Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical and computational research to improve the first-principles-based theoretical description of strongly correlated materials through the incorporation of quantum many-body theory methods like dynamical mean field theory and to investigate properties, ordered states, and associated phenomena of strongly correlated materials. The PI will develop many-body concepts analytical methods and computational techniques to investigate the properties of correlated metals insulators and superconductors. The PI will study the physical properties of Hunds metals such as the iron pnictides and chalcogenides. All these materials are "bad metals" at high temperatures. The PI will develop a theory of transport in a regime where materials are not well described by Fermi liquid theory. The PI will investigate the unusual thermoelectric properties of correlated insulators such as iron silicide and antimonide, in and out of equilibrium. In the long term, the PI envisions the construction of a framework for predicting and understanding the physical properties of correlated materials, building on the successes of the Dynamical Mean Field Theory. This framework would enable the computational design of materials with strongly correlated electron systems, starting from first principles.

The PI plans to develop an interactive website which will serve as an archive of computationally intensive results for various materials.

NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical and computational research to improve materials-specific theoretical descriptions of materials in which electrons strongly interact with each other leading to strong correlations in electronic motion and unusual materials property and phenomena. Modern solid-state physics explains the physical properties of numerous materials, such as traditional metals, semiconductors, and insulators which provide the basis of our modern technological society. But materials with electrons derived from d- and f-electron shells tend to fall outside the scope of this theory and have remarkable properties. Examples include: iron pnictide materials which exhibit high temperature superconductivity where electrons flow in the absence of resistance, and iron silicide and iron antimonide which exhibit exceptionally large thermoelectricity where large temperature differences develop at different areas of the material when an electric field is applied. The PI will develop concepts, techniques, and computational tools to describe this class of materials and elucidate the origin of their remarkable properties

The PI plans to develop an interactive website which will serve as an archive of computationally intensive results for various materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Materials  form  the foundation of the technologies that we  employ in our daily life, and improving their  properties is key for  discoveries that will improve  the well being of future generations. Our research efforts are centered in advancing the methods needed to predict the properties of strongly correlated materials.  These are systems for which  the traditional methods of solid state theory, which pictures the electricity  carriers in a  solid in terms of non interacting electrons moving in an an average self consistent periodic potential  does not work.

Strongly  correlated solids drive a wealth of new and unusual physical properties, such as high temperature superconductivity which enables the flow of electric currents without resistance and generates large magnetic fields which can be used for imaging in MRI machines. They feature ultrafast nonlinear optical and electric responses,  and serve as fast switches and new memory devices. This phenomena takes place far from equilibrium where new  structures form and new physical principles and techniques are required for their description.

The goal of this NSF funded project is to develop the methods ( concepts, theory, algorithms and computer codes) needed to  understand the  physical properties of strongly correlated materials in and out of equilibrium. The ultimate goal is to reach accurate predicted power in the field of strongly correlated electron systems, to dramatically accelerate the process of material discovery and design. For this purpose, we  develop  new concepts and new computational tools and test them against available experimental data and  make predictions for future experiments.

An important concept that we developed in this grant, is that of a Hunds metal. Materials where the  strong correlations arise from the atomic Hunds coupling, and is characterized by multiple energy scales  for their spin and orbital correlations. An important method developed in this grant, is the Dynamical Mean Field Theory (DMFT). It pictures  the  solid  in terms of  strongly correlated  atomic shells embedded in a  bath of non interacting electrons, which enable fluctuations between the different atomic configurations. This is picture in figure 1. 

This approach yields new physical intuition into complex correlated materials and allows the computation of their physical properties in parameter regimes where standard method of condensed matter physics does not work well. The equations are still very complex, and  in this funding period  we succeeded for the first time in solving the  DMFT equations exactly at all temperatures by  implementing  DMFT+NRG in collaboration with J. VonDelft group in Munich. This  dramatic advance gave new insights into the Hunds metals, as the existence of a broad regime where the spins are localized but the orbitals are fully itinerant ( orbital-spin separation). This is illustrated in figure. 2. 

Our research combines the building of simplified many body Hamiltonians to understand qualitative aspects of strong correlation phenomena at low energies with the computationally intensive calculations that model more accurately the microscopic complexity of real materials, for example the LDA+DMFT method was introduced with the support of this grant, and in this funding period we adapted it to the study of transport properties of the Ruthenates (arguably the simplest  physical realization of the Hund's metal ). This is shown in figure 3, where we highlight that the approach is most reliable  as we move away from a strictly two dimensional situation. This  comparison of theory and experiment is particularly exciting, as we can now  have  established the reliability  of the LDA+DMFT method  making  the exploration of materials which have not yet been synthesized experimentally.  It also allows us to focus  the  method development in the treatment of deviations from DMFT due to two dimensional fluctuations.

We have also extended the DMFT methodology to  describe and predict the spin fluctuation spectra and applied it the iron pnictide superconductors, as described in figure 4. Whenever comparison with experiment is possible, the theory agrees well with experiment. The results show tha superconductivity requires commensurate spin flucatuions narrow frequency range which is not too low or too high. It is very exciting to see how, through the support of basic science research, we have now tools to understand and quantitatively describe materials which  were considered to be amenable to only phenomenological treatments when this line of research began.

Other successes in the last funding period is the development of a methodology to compute the electronic and magnetic polarization of correlated insulators and propose a theory of electric field driving resistive switching, advancing from the modeling of idealized solids towards  the basic science needed to  possible device applications.
